Posts.Content: Hi, That's brilliant advise. I'm a carer and although my partners cancer is bowel, sometimes it's hard not to be positive and the tears come. I've tried this timer and it works for me. Thanks for sharing this. Lots of hugs and positive vibes to everyone. Xxxx
Posts.Title: Chest Wall Recurrence

Posts.Content: Hi Mark, I too am a carer and struggling to cope with my partners diagnosis. He has bowel cancer, and had a sigmoid colectomy only yesterday. But it's been diagnosed nearly 3 months ago and we've had to go through a roller coaster ride of further tests and waiting for results, and then more waiting for mdt decisions. I nearly had a nervous breakdown, but was referred to a councillor by our McMillan nurse. She's helped me cope a bit better, with help from my gp and district nurses who have been looking after johns wounds following a lung biopsy. I too feel helpless at times and I feel guilty for feeling down as its not my illness. Both myself and John try to talk to each other about our feelings, and we take everything one day at a time. John may need chemo next, once he's over his surgery, and I'm sure that will bring more emotions. Keep in touch, it helps to read everyone else's experiences. I hope you and your wife get some positive news soon. Lots of hugs and positive vibes for you both. Sharon
Posts.Title: Help from a partner / husbands point of view?

Posts.Content: Oh and one more thing, try to do something nice together every day, even if it's just to go for a short walk holding hands. You both need to have some sort of a distraction so it enables you to think of something else, even if it's just for 15 mins. Otherwise the cancer is on your mind 24 hours a day and there's no escape. Xxx
